## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-10-31T12:39:24Z
## Message ID: 20161031-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-10-31T09:25Z  in a continuation of the radiation belt enhancement that has been ongoing since 2016-10-26T11:00Z (see recent notifications 20161026-AL-001, 20161026-AL-002, 20161028-AL-001, and 20161030-AL-001).

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-10-25T09:29Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-10-31T09:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 19, 2016 - October 25, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-10-26T20:23:47Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-10-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-10-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161026-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that this C-type CME starting around 2016-10-25T19:12Z may impact STEREO A at 2016-10-28T21:35Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20161026-AL-004).  

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period of 2016-10-25T12:00Z-15:00Z.  It then reached moderate levels of Kp=6 on the following synoptic period and has remained between Kp=6 and Kp=5 ever since.  This strong increase in geomagnetic activity is associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-10-25 (see notifications 20161025-AL-001 and 20161025-AL-002).  The solar wind speed reached very high values of ~830 km/s at the end of the day on 2016-10-25.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period from 2016-10-19 to 2016-10-22 due to the effects of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-10-15 (see notifications 20161019-AL-001 and 20161021-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the electron flux enhancement at the outer radiation belt described above. 

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-10-25T19:12Z     ~560            C              -145/10                42                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-10-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-11-01T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. The active region in the field view of STEREO A giving off the C-type CME mentioned above has potential for further eruptions. The Earth is expected to be impacted by additional high speed solar wind streams. Geomagnetic activity is currently moderate with Kp reaching level 6 during the synoptic period of 2016-10-26T09:00Z-12:00Z and with the > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux enhancement starting at 2016-10-26T11:00Z and ongoing, both events associated with the coronal hole high speed stream that started on 2016-10-25 (see notifications  20161026-AL-001, 20161026-AL-002, and 20161026-AL-003). 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-10-26T16:20:09Z
## Message ID: 20161026-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-10-25T19:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~560 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 42 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -145/10 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-10-25T19:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2016-10-28T21:35Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-10-25T19:12:00-CME-001):

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-10-26T12:39:22Z
## Message ID: 20161026-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-10-26T09:00Z to 2016-10-26T12:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-10-25T09:29Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-10-25T12:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 12, 2016 - October 18, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-10-19T17:00:21Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-10-12T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-10-18T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161019-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period with just a handful C-class flares and one C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with the Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic periods 2016-10-13T15:00Z to 2016-10-13T21:00Z and 2016-10-14T00:00Z to 2016-10-14T03:00Z.  The moderate geomagnetic activity was due to the arrival of a CME starting at the Sun on 2016-10-08T21:09Z that arrived at DSCOVR at L1 on 2016-10-12T21:21Z (see notification 20161013-AL-001).  Later, the geomagnetic Kp index reached level 5 (minor) during the synoptic periods 2016-10-16T18:00Z to 2016-10-16T21:00Z due to a high speed stream starting on 2016-10-15.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-10-17T12:10Z and remains elevated (see notifications 20161017-AL-001 - 003).  The enhancement is due to the high speed stream starting on 2016-10-15 and intesified to 750 km/s on 2016-10-16 and 2016-10-17.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week expcept for the periods of moderate geomagnetic activity and radiation belt electron flux enhancement described above.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-10-14T16:48Z     ~621            C               -93/-24               25                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-10-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-10-25T23:59Z
 
Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate with > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux enhancement possible during the ongoing high speed stream that started on 2016-10-15. Elevated acitivty may again occur between 2016-10-24 to 2016-10-26 when another high speed stream is expected to arrive with speeds of 700-800 km/s.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 05, 2016 - October 11, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-10-12T20:47:17Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-10-05T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-10-11T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161012-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt measured by GOES 13 crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-10-06T16:45Z in a continuation of the radiation belt enhancement that started on 2016-09-27T16:50Z (see notifications 20161003-AL-001, 20161006-AL-001, 20161006-AL-002 and 20161006-AL-003).  The elevated energetic electron flux levels were caused by the the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 starting at 2016-09-26T07:05Z, with additional influence from the flank impact of the CME with ID 2016-10-01T03:09:00-CME-001 that arrived around 2016-10-04T11:30Z (see notification 20161002-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevation of the electron fluxes in the outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:

None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-10-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-10-18T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming reporting period.  The active regions on the disk appear to have low magnetic complexity.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be slightly elevated at the end of 2016-10-13 or the beginning of 2016-10-14 due to the influence of a slow coronal mass ejection detected by STEREO A/SOHO coronagraphs starting on 2016-10-08T21:09Z.

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-10-01T03:09Z.

Estimated speed: ~535 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 23 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -65/7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-10-01T03:09:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-10-01T14:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~524 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 23 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -73/18 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2016-10-01T14:24:00-CME-001

3: S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-10-01T14:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~294 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 32 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 100/17 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2016-10-01T14:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Mars and Spitzer (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CMEs will reach Mars at 2016-10-05T15:13Z and Spitzer at 2016-10-04T16:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).
